item.title: The default place-of-record for writers
item.description:
I would love to see a university-based open source project to create a Medium-like service, run as a non-profit, written and maintained by students, with the help of teachers of course, funded by foundations and contributors.

The mistake we keep making is relying VCs to create a simple default place-of-record for writing on the internet. Medium has a great user interface, but because they had to find an elusive business model, it kept changing what it was.

I honestly don't think it's possible to create a default place-of-record for writing with a business model attached.

The university that took this project on would have a long-term source of project funding, and their students would learn more than computer science, they'd learn how to create and support a real world system that means something.

And if I recall correctly college students are often searching for that kind of experience, to do meaningful work with their talents.
item.source:markdown:
I would love to see a university-based open source project to create a Medium-like service, run as a non-profit, written and maintained by students, with the help of teachers of course, funded by foundations and contributors.
The mistake we keep making is relying VCs to create a simple default place-of-record for writing on the internet. Medium has a great user interface, but because they had to find an elusive business model, it kept changing what it was.
I honestly don't think it's possible to create a default place-of-record for writing with a business model attached.
The university that took this project on would have a long-term source of project funding, and their students would learn more than computer science, they'd learn how to create and support a real world system that means something.
And if I recall correctly college students are often searching for that kind of experience, to do meaningful work with their talents.

item.description:
@johnrobb thanks john -- i'd say it's been stagnant not frozen.

no reason it couldn't move, it's just that people didn't know how to do it or want to do the work needed.

i do think you'll like where it's going. ;-)

@kevin2kelly @stevenbjohnson I like to take problems on a walk. There’s something I’m not going to solve when I’m sitting at my computer screen, just need to relax a bit let my mind wander and after while my options are clear and I can see which way to go.
item.source:markdown: @kevin2kelly @stevenbjohnson I like to take problems on a walk. There’s something I’m not going to solve when I’m sitting at my computer screen, just need to relax a bit let my mind wander and after while my options are clear and I can see which way to go.

item.description: @AdamSinger @louisgray yes louis is great. say hi to him for me. i was kind disappointed when he disappeared into google. not my favorite company in the world. ;-)
item.source:markdown: @AdamSinger @louisgray yes louis is great. say hi to him for me. i was kind disappointed when he disappeared into google. not my favorite company in the world. ;-)

item.description: @trickjarrett thanks for letting me know. ;-)
item.source:markdown: @trickjarrett thanks for letting me know. ;-)

item.description:
@AdamSinger I wrote in one of my recent pieces that it would be great if a foundation came up with a grant for a nonprofit to provide hosting of text documents like medium and substack. just as a backup for people who are happy with substack.

@AdamSinger the choice shouldn't be between having to deal with the pain of hosting or giving up on having your writing survive me.

i find that having a backup of stuff i wrote 20 years ago is actually incredibly important, so i can piece together why i gave up on RSS, for example.

@AdamSinger to go off on a tangent, i loved the Get Back movie on Disney about the Beatles. everyone thought the Let It Be sessions were a disaster, but they weren't. even paul mccartney thought they were. but he was great!

people's memories are very undependable.

@AdamSinger i am starting a reboot of RSS right now, and all i remembered was the shitty stuff. but as the lights just begin to start coming back on, i also (now) remember the really wonderful people i worked with on this stuff. i just remember the assholes!! so weird.

@AdamSinger but it's all there in my blog notes from 2002. but if i didn't have them i'd have totally the wrong idea about what happened.

@AdamSinger you might do something that matters to you in 20 years, and since you write so well, what a terrible loss it would be if you couldnt access it.

@AdamSinger you should have it both ways. there's no reason to give on writing for the record.

@AdamSinger Hmmm. Just because you had a bad experience hosting your own site doesn't mean it is impossible for anyone but Substack to keep hosting you. You're really smart so I know you know that. I'm smart too so come -- let's be respectful.
item.source:markdown: @AdamSinger Hmmm. Just because you had a bad experience hosting your own site doesn't mean it is impossible for anyone but Substack to keep hosting you. You're really smart so I know you know that. I'm smart too so come -- let's be respectful.

item.description: @AJCGlobal @biannagolodryga @CobbSchools Until recently a few southern states had the stars and bars in their state flags. Black people look at that symbol the same way we look at Nazi signage.
